Fig. 1 NO x conversion (a) and N2 selectivity (b) of Ce x /HBEA catalysts in the presence of C3H6. Conditions: 500ppm NO+500ppm NH3 +500ppmC3H6 +5% O2 +N2 balance, GHSV=150,000h−1. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 NO x conversion over Ce x /HBEA catalysts with and without C3H6 at 350°C. Conditions: 500ppm NO+500ppm NH3 +500ppmC3H6 (if added)+5% O2 +N2 balance, GHSV=150,000h−1. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The effects of C3H6 and H2O on the NO x conversion of Ce48/HBEA catalyst. Conditions: 500ppm NO+500ppm NH3 +500ppmC3H6 (if added)+5% H2O (if added)+5% O2 +N2 balance, GHSV=150,000h−1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The C3H6 oxidation during NH3-SCR in the presence of C3H6. (a) C3H6 conversion of Ce x /HBEA catalysts, (b) CO2 and CO concentration over Ce48/HBEA. Conditions: 500ppm NO+500ppm NH3 +500ppmC3H6 +5% O2 +N2 balance, GHSV=150,000h−1. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD spectrum of Ce x /HBEA catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 XPS spectrum of Ce x /HBEA catalysts (a), and XPS spectrum of fresh and coked Ce1/HBEA catalysts (b). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 TPD profiles of NH3 (a) and C3H6 (b) over HBEA, Ce48/HBEA and CeO2 catalyst. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 HRTEM micrographs of (a) HBEA and (b) Ce48/HBEA; EDS line scans over the catalyst particle (top) and the corresponding Ce, Si, Al and O signal distribution (bottom) of (c) HBEA and (d) Ce48/HBEA. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The DRIFTS spectra of adsorbed species in a flow of 500ppmC3H6 +5% O2 +N2 balance over HBEA, Ce1/HBEA and Ce48/HBEA at 350°C. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The DRIFTS spectra of adsorbed species over HBEA (a) and Ce48/HBEA (b) at 350°C in a flow of 1000ppm NO+1000ppm NH3 +500ppmC3H6 (when used)+5% O2 +N2 balance for 20min. Fig. 10 Table 1 Comparison of specific surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter of fresh and propene poisoned catalysts. Table 1 Catalyst Surface area(m2 g−1) Total pore volume(cm3 g−1) Average pore diameter(nm) HBEA 495.1 0.67 5.41 HBEA-HC a 184.8 0.21 4.56 Ce48/HBEA 208.3 0.24 4.54 Ce48/HBEA-HC 199.1 0.19 4.49 CeO2 70.0 0.23 8.06 a Ce48/HBEA-HC presents propene poisoned catalysts obtained by treating fresh catalyst with 500ppm C3H6 and 5%O2/N2 as balance at 500°C for 30min. Table 2 The content of carbonaceous deposits on the propene poisoned catalysts. Table 2 Sample HBEA-HC Ce48/HBEA-HC Carbonaceous deposit content (wt. %) 6.5 2.6 Table 3 The gas adsorption capacity of the catalysts (μmolg−1). Table 3 TPD HBEA Ce48/HBEA CeO2 NH3 436 161 4 C3H6 2055 551 0 Editor’s choice paper Promotional effect of CeO2 on the propene poisoning resistance of HBEA zeolite catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO x Yun Shi a b Xiaoxiang Wang a Yinfeng Xia b Cheng Sun a Chongjian Zhao a Sujing Li a ⁎ Wei Li a a Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education, Institute of Industrial Ecology and Environment, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310027, China Key Laboratory of Biomass Chemical Engineering of Ministry of Education Institute of Industrial Ecology and Environment Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310027 China b Institute of Environmental Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310058, China Institute of Environmental Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310058 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The improvement of hydrocarbon resistance is a challenge for developing HBEA zeolite-based catalysts for NH3-SCR of NO x from diesel engine exhausts. HBEA zeolite was deactivated rapidly by propene during the NH3 selective catalytic reduction of NO x . The carbonaceous deposits formed by incomplete combustion of propene were responsible for the deactivation. The propene poisoning resistance of HBEA catalyst could be improved by doping CeO2. The Ce x /HBEA catalyst was prepared by impregnation method. The Ce48/HBEA catalyst showed the highest NO x conversion among the prepared catalysts. In the presence of propene, NO x conversion of Ce48/HBEA was above 92% in the temperature range of 300–450°C with GHSV of 150,000h−1. The N2 selectivity was above 96% between 175°C and 500°C for the Ce48/HBEA catalyst. Moreover, HBEA coated by CeO2 core-shell structure was formed in the Ce48/HBEA catalyst. Propene was mainly oxidized to CO2 by O2 over the CeO2 shell, which protected HBEA from propene poisoning. NH4 + and COO− as intermediates during NH3-SCR of NO x in the presence of C3H6 was observed on the DRIFTS spectra. These results show that the Ce48/HBEA catalyst with the core-shell structure is a potential candidate to control NO x emissions from diesel engine. Keywords CeO2 Core-shell structure Propene poisoning resistance NH3-SCR catalyst DRIFTS 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ) play a major role in the formation of haze and acid rain. Diesel engine is a major source of NO x emission because it has been widely used in vehicles, ships and stationary power applications [1]. NH3 selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) of NO x , using urea as the ammonia source, is recognized as an effective technology to control NO x emissions from diesel engines [2,3]. Nowadays, vanadia-based catalysts (V2O5-WO3/TiO2) are the common commercial SCR catalysts. However, V2O5 has biological toxicity and the V2O5-WO3/TiO2 can be deactivated by the phase change of TiO2 at high temperatures [4]. These drawbacks limit the application of V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalysts in diesel engines. Metal-containing zeolites are promising catalysts for NH3-SCR of NO x due to their excellent catalytic activity and N2 selectivity. Numerous zeolites have been investigated as the supports for NH3-SCR catalysts, such as HBEA [5], SSZ-13 [6], SAPO-34 [7] and ZSM-5 [8]. Among them, HBEA zeolite has large surface areas and abundant acid sites [9]. These features make HBEA a promising support for SCR catalysts. However, diesel engine exhaust contains unburned hydrocarbons (HCs) which can deactivate the HBEA-based catalysts [10]. Propene is a typical component of the unburned HCs. In the presence of propene, carbonaceous deposits can be easily formed on the acid sites of HBEA during NH3-SCR reaction [11]. which can cause the deactivation of HBEA catalysts [12]. Thus, the improvement of hydrocarbon resistance is a challenge for developing HBEA zeolite-based NH3-SCR catalysts. Doping transition metal oxides over HBEA is an effective method to improve the hydrocarbon resistance of HBEA-based SCR catalysts [13–16]. Therefore, Metal-containing HBEA catalysts, such as Fe-BEA [5], Cu-BEA [17,18] and Co-BEA [19], have attracted extensive attentions as NH3-SCR catalysts. However, the effect of CeO2 on the propene poisoning resistance of HBEA catalyst has not been reported yet. Ceria is an inexpensive rare earth oxide. A lot of ceria-containing catalysts showed excellent NH3-SCR activity, such as, CeO2-WO3 [20], sulfated CeO2 [21], CeO2/TiO2 [22], and Ce-ZSM-5 [23]. The redox cycle between Ce4+ and Ce3+ is responsible for releasing and storing oxygen [24], which could accelerate the NH3-SCR activity and the oxidation of HCs to CO2. Thus, ceria is also used as an oxygen storage component for three-way catalysts (TWCs) to control HCs, CO and NO x emissions from automobile exhausts [25]. These features make ceria a potential doping-component to improve the carbon deposition resistance of HBEA catalyst. The doping of ceria on HBEA catalyst could be a promising way to promote hydrocarbon resistance and NH3-SCR activity. In this work, Ce x /HBEA catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. The effects of propene on the NH3-SCR activity of Ce x /HBEA catalysts were studied. The promotional effects of CeO2 on the propene poisoning resistance of HBEA-based catalysts were further investigated. These results will shed lights on developing highly active zeolite-based catalysts for NH3-SCR of NO x from diesel engine exhausts. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate ( Ce ( NO 3 ) 3 · 6 H 2 O ), provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd., was calcined at 550°C for 4h in air to obtain CeO2 catalyst. HBEA (SiO2/Al2O3 =25) was provided by Nankai University Catalyst Co., Ltd. The catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. 3.0g HBEA powder was mixed with 3mL Ce(NO)3 solution to form Ce(NO)3/HBEA slurry. The slurry was dried by vacuum freeze drying technology after stirring for 8h at room temperature. Afterwards, the catalyst was calcined at 550°C for 4h in air and then sieved to 40–60 mesh. The obtained catalyst was named as Ce x /HBEA, where x (wt%) was calculated as CeO2 content. Propene poisoned catalysts, denoted as Ce x /HBEA-HC, were obtained by treating fresh catalyst with 500ppm C3H6 and 5%O2/N2 as balance at 500°C for 30min. 2.2 Catalytic activity test Catalytic activity tests were performed in a fixed bed quartz tube reactor. The quartz tube, with an internal diameter of 6mm, was placed inside a temperature-controlled furnace. Then, the catalyst was placed in the center of the quartz tube. A K-type thermocouple was inserted in the catalyst bed to measure the reaction temperature. The fresh catalysts were first activated at 500°C for 30min in a flow of 10% O2/N2 to remove adsorbed species. Afterwards, a reaction mixture containing 500ppm NO, 500ppm NH3, 500ppm C3H6 (if added), 5% O2 and N2 as balance was introduced into the reactor. The reaction temperature was increased from 175°C to 500°C with an interval of 25°C. Each step was lasted 30min to obtain steady state conditions. The total flow rate was 500mLmin−1, corresponding to a GHSV (gas hourly space velocity) of 150,000h−1. Reactants and products were analyzed by a Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer coupled with a heated gas cell (Pike Technologies, optical path length=2.4m). The conversion and N2 selectivity were calculated by the following equations. (1) NO x conversion = C X ( i n ) − C X ( o u t ) C X ( i n ) × 100 % (2) C 3 H 6 conversion = C C O 2 + C C O 3 × C C 3 H 6 × 100 % (3) N 2 s e l e c t i v i t y = ( 1 − 2 × C N 2 O C N O ( i n ) + N O 2 ( i n ) + N H 3 ( i n ) − C N O ( o u t ) + N O 2 ( o u t ) + N H 3 ( o u t ) ) × 100 where NO x represents NO and NO2. 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD spectra were recorded over a 2θ range of 5–90° using an X-ray diffractometer (PANalytical X’ Pert PRO, Holland) with Cu-Kα (λ=0.15406nm) radiation at 40kV and 40mA. The morphology of the samples was studied by high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100F, Japan). The chemical analysis was obtained by energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi) was used to analyze the atomic chemical state on each catalyst. A Quantachrome Nova Autosorb-IQ-MP system was used to determine the specific surface area and the average pore diameter of the catalysts. A thermo-gravimetric analysis (TGA, SDT Q600) was utilized to determine the carbonaceous deposit content on propene poisoned catalysts. The propene poisoned catalysts (6.0mg) were heated from room temperature to 800°C at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 in a flow of 5%O2/N2. Temperature-programed desorption (TPD) were conducted by the SCR activity test reactor system. The 0.15g sample was pretreated at 500°C in 10% O2/N2 for 30min and then purged by a N2 flow for 20min, and then cooled down to 100°C. Then, a 500mLmin−1 gas mixture (500ppm NH3/N2 or 500ppm C3H6/N2) was passed through the sample bed at 100°C for 30min. Afterwards, the sample was purged with N2 at 100°C for 60min to remove the weakly adsorbed gases, followed by a temperature ramp (100–900°C) at a rate of 10°Cmin−1 in N2 (400mLmin−1). In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) spectra were collected using Nicolet-6700 spectrometer coupled with a high temperature environmental cell fitted with KBr window and an MCT detector cooled with liquid N2. The catalyst was placed in the cell and heated to 350°C in a flow of 100mlmin−1 N2 for 30min to remove adsorbed impurities. The DRIFTS spectra, referenced to a N2 background, were collected using 4cm−1 resolution and co-addition of 64 scans. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR performance of Cex/HBEA catalysts NO x conversion and N2 selectivity as a function of reaction temperature between 175 and 500°C are shown in Fig. 1 . The feed gas mixture contained 500ppm NO, 500ppm NH3, 500ppmC3H6, 5% O2 and N2 as balance, corresponding to a GHSV of 150,000h−1. The results show that pure HBEA catalyst had a poor activity and the NO x conversion did not exceed 38% in the temperature range of 175–500°C. The NO x conversion was substantially increased after addition of cerium. The order of NO x conversion was ranked as Ce48/HBEA>Ce60/HBEA>Ce36/HBEA>Ce24/HBEA>Ce12/HBEA>Ce1/HBEA>HBEA. The Ce48/HBEA catalyst exhibited the highest NO x conversion of the catalysts tested. The NO x conversion of Ce48/HBEA increased from 26% at 175°C to 84% at 275°C and was maintained at about 96% between 300 and 425°C. Afterwards, it started to decrease with increasing temperature and reached 82% at 500°C. At high temperatures, the decrease in NO x conversion was attributed to the competitive NH3 oxidation by O2 to NO x and N2 [26], leading to a lack of NH3 for the NO x reduction. Furthermore, N2O is a strong greenhouse gas and destroys the ozone layer. Its effect as a greenhouse gas is 300-fold stronger than that of CO2 [27]. Thus, the formation of N2O during NH3-SCR of NO x should be constrained. The N2O formation was inhibited by adding cerium in HBEA and the N2 selectivity was improved, as shown in Fig. 1b. The N2 selectivity was above 96% between 175°C and 500°C for the Ce48/HBEA catalysts, while N2 selectivity of pure HBEA catalyst was only 78% at 500°C. Fig. 2 shows the NO x conversion over Ce x /HBEA catalysts with and without C3H6 at 350°C. It is worth noting that the NO x conversion of Ce48/HBEA with and without C3H6 was the same. However, when propene was added to gas mixture, the NO x conversion of HBEA and Ce1/HBEA was sharply decreased by 48% and 47% at 350°C, respectively. This indicates that HBEA catalyst is susceptible to be deactivated by propene. In contrast, the NO x conversion of CeO2 was increased by 7% in the presence of propene. It has been reported that NO x could be reduced by C3H6 (HC-SCR) over CeO2-containing catalysts [28]. Thus, in the coexistence of NH3 and C3H6 in the gas mixture, both HC-SCR and NH3-SCR reaction pathways co-exist, leading to the increase of NO x conversion over CeO2 catalysts. In order to further study the effects of C3H6 on the catalytic activity at different temperatures, the NO x conversion of Ce48/HBEA catalyst with and without propene is shown in Fig. 3 . After C3H6 was added to the feed gas, the NO x conversion was decreased at temperature below 300°C, but it was increased at temperature higher than 375°C. At low temperatures, the decrease in NO x conversion is probably due to the competitive adsorption between C3H6 and reactants on the catalyst surface, and the inhibition of NO oxidation to NO2 [12]. At high temperatures, C3H6 could also reduce the NO x adspecies in the presence of excess oxygen through HC-SCR reaction [29]. These results suggest that the presence of CeO2 could improve the propene poisoning tolerance of HBEA, especially in the high temperature (325–500°C). In practice, diesel engine exhaust also contains water vapor. To simulate the real composition of diesel exhaust, 5% H2O was added in the feed. As shown in Fig. 3, after 5% H2O was added into the feed gas, the NO x conversion was decreased at temperature lower than 400°C owing to competitive adsorption of H2O and reactants (NO x or/and NH3) [30]. However, the presence of H2O promoted the catalytic activity of Ce48/HBEA at higher temperatures. This may be due to the suppression of over-oxidation of NH3. At 500°C, NO x conversion of Ce48/HBEA increased from 82% to 95% when H2O was added. 3.2 C3H6 oxidation analysis The C3H6 conversion was calculated from CO2 and CO produced (equation 2). As shown in Fig. 4 a, C3H6 conversion was increased by doping CeO2 over HBEA. The C3H6 conversion of Ce48/HBEA is much higher than that of HBEA. The C3H6 conversion of Ce48/HBEA reaches 95% at 425°C, while the C3H6 conversion of HBEA is only 21%. This indicates that most of C3H6 was oxidized to CO2 and CO over the Ce48/HBEA catalyst. As shown in Figs. 1 and 2, the NO x reduction of HBEA catalyst was obviously inhibited by C3H6. The inhibition was caused by carbonaceous deposits formed on the surface of zeolite catalysts during C3H6 oxidation [31]. When CeO2 was introduced into HBEA catalyst, C3H6 was more likely to be oxidized to CO and CO2. The concentration of CO2 and CO during NH3-SCR in the presence of C3H6 over Ce48/HBEA was shown in Fig. 4b. The results show that CO2 is the major product. Also, the CO concentration reached 350–450ppm in the temperature range of 375°C to 475°C. CO is known as reductant. It is necessary to investigate whether NO x can be reduced by CO. Fig. S1 (S.I.) presents the catalytic reduction of NO x using CO as the reductant over Ce48/HBEA. The results shows that CO cannot continue to react with NO x at high temperature in presence of catalysts. And CO will be oxidized to CO2 at high temperatures by O2 over Ce48/HBEA. 3.3 Crystallite characterization XRD patterns of prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . In the XRD pattern of HBEA, two typical reflections appeared at 7.8° and 22.5°, respectively. The peak near 22.5° is generally taken as evidence of lattice contraction/expansion of the β structure [32]. The typical reflections of CeO2 match well with the JCPDS (card no. 43-1002) data. Plane (111) is the most exposed and stable plane with the strongest XRD reflection [33]. After loading of CeO2 over HBEA, the intensity of HBEA reflections decreased with the increase of CeO2 loading amount. It is worth noting that the reflections of HBEA could hardly be observed when the loading amount of CeO2 reached 48%, and typical reflections of CeO2 were observed in the XRD pattern of Ce48/HBEA catalyst. This indicates that CeO2 was formed over Ce48/HBEA catalyst. The CeO2 reflection intensity of Ce48/HBEA is almost the same as pure CeO2 and is much stronger than that of HBEA, which may be due to HBEA was coated by the CeO2. Whereas, no reflections of CeO2 are observed in the XRD pattern of Ce1/HBEA. This indicates that Ce was introduced into the structure of HBEA zeolite by ion exchange, and/or the CeO2 species were highly dispersed over HBEA. According to the results of catalytic activity test in the presence of propene, the NO x conversion of Ce x /HBEA catalyst improved with the increase of Ce doping amounts. At the same times, the intensity of CeO2 reflection in the XRD pattern became stronger. Al and Si sites in HBEA zeolites usually were related with Brønsted acid sites (Si-OH and Si-OH-Al), which could activate NH3, but also could lead to carbonaceous deposit. The impregnation of cerium could block some Al and Si sites, and with the optimal Ce amount, so Ce48/HBEA not only had high activity in high temperature region, but also had good propene poisoning resistance. 3.4 Cerium valence analysis The chemical valence change of cerium were analyzed by XPS. The XPS spectra of the Ce 3d peaks were deconvoluted by fitting a Gaussian function to the experimental data. The deconvoluted peak positions were optimized according to the same procedure for all samples to achieve the lowest standard deviation X2 . Fig. 6 a shows the Ce 3d spectra and the corresponding deconvolution. The bands, labeled as v, v″, v‴ and u, u″, u‴, are attributed to Ce4+ while v′ and u′ are attributed to Ce3+ [34]. The ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3+ +Ce4+) over Ce x /HBEA catalyst decreased with the increase of CeO2 loading, 0.78 for Ce1/HBEA, 0.45 for Ce12/HBEA, and 0.08 for Ce48/HBEA, respectively. Some Ce3+ species were considered to be formed by replacing H+ by Ce3+ at cation exchange sites of HBEA. The catalytic activity of Ce1/HBEA was decreased sharply by C3H6. Fig. 6b shows that Ce3+ is the dominating cerium species in the Ce1/HBEA catalyst. Nevertheless, the magnitude of the Ce3+ peak decreased obvously after propene exposure. It was inferred that the decrease of Ce3+ resulted from propene poisoning, and Ce3+ species on the surface of Ce1/HBEA were easily deactivated by propene. Ce4+ species originated from CeO2 had stronger oxidation capacity as compared with Ce3+ species. The presence of Ce4+ could promote the oxidation of NO to NO2, hence enhancing the SCR activity by facilitating the “fast SCR” reaction [35,36]. On the other hand, high ratio of Ce4+/(Ce3+ +Ce4+) over Ce48/HBEA catalyst was helpful to oxidize propene to CO2 and inhibit the formation of carbonaceous deposits, resulting in the better propene poisoning resistance of Ce48/HBEA catalyst than that of Ce1/HBEA catalyst. 3.5 Surface area and pore structure analysis of catalysts The catalytic activity of NH3-SCR of NO x was related to the surface area of the catalyst. In order to investigate the effects of CeO2 doping, the catalytic activity, surface area and porosity of fresh and propene poisoned catalysts are shown in Table 1 . After poisoned by propene, surface area of HBEA was decreased by 63%. However, surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter of propene poisoned Ce48/HBEA were slightly decreased compared with those of the fresh one. Because CeO2 is a strong oxidant which can catalyze carbonaceous deposit to CO and CO2, the aggregation of carbonaceous particles on the surface of catalysts might be inhibited by doping CeO2. After poisoned by propene, the color of HBEA changed from white to black brown while the color of CeO2 did not change, confirming that carbonaceous deposits were more easily formed on HBEA surface. This could also be proved by the content of carbonaceous deposits on the propene poisoned catalysts. As shown in Table 2 , the carbonaceous deposit content was analyzed by TGA based on the weight loss caused by carbonaceous deposits combustion at high temperatures. The carbonaceous deposit content of HBEA-HC (6.5wt. %) was higher than that of Ce48/HBEA-HC (2.6wt. %). The formation of carbonaceous deposits could cover the active sites and block the pores on the catalyst surface, resulting in deactivation of the catalysts [37]. CeO2 could promote the oxidation of C3H6 to CO2 and then inhibit the propene poisoning on HBEA zeolite. Thus, the surface area of Ce48/HBEA was hardly affected by C3H6, and the Ce48/HBEA catalyst exhibited high NH3-SCR activity. 3.6 Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 and C3H6 In order to investigate the effects of CeO2 doping on the acidity of the Ce x /HBEA catalysts, NH3 and C3H6 TPD experiments were studied. Fig. 7 a shows the NH3 TPD profiles of HBEA, Ce48/HBEA and CeO2 catalysts. A shoulder desorption peak of NH3 at around 215°C and 300°C was observed for HBEA catalyst. The low-temperature peak was assigned to weakly adsorbed NH3, such as physically adsorbed NH3 and NH3 adsorbed on weak Lewis acid sites [37,38]. The high-temperature peak was related to Brönsted acid sites in the zeolite structure (Si-O(H)-Al) [39]. Comparing the NH3-TPD profiles, the intensity of NH3 desorption peak decreased obviously for Ce48/HBEA. The amount of acid sites on Ce48/HBEA was lower than HBEA, as shown in Table 3 . Furthermore, only a small peak at low temperature appeared in the NH3-TPD profile of CeO2. This means that Brönsted acid sites hardly existed on the surface of CeO2. The CeO2 catalyst presented quite low adsorption capacities for NH3 (4μmolg−1) as compared with HBEA (436μmolg−1) and Ce48/HBEA (161μmolg−1). Fig. 7b shows the C3H6 TPD profiles of HBEA, Ce48/HBEA and CeO2 catalysts. A C3H6 desorption peak at around 240°C was observed for both HBEA and Ce48/HBEA, and the peak intensity of HBEA was much higher than that of Ce48/HBEA. No C3H6 desorption peak was observed for CeO2. The order of C3H6 adsorption capacity was HBEA (2055μmolg−1)>Ce48/HBEA (551μmolg−1)>CeO2 (0μmolg−1). These results show that C3H6 was prone to be adsorbed on HBEA and Ce48/HBEA catalysts. It is known that acid sites on the catalyst play an important role in the NH3-SCR reaction. NH3 is adsorbed on the acid sites and activated to NH2 or NH4 + to participate in the NO x reduction [2]. However, the formation of carbonaceous deposits is also related to the acidity amount of zeolite catalysts because hydrocarbons are activated on the acid sites [31]. The presence of C3H6 could lead to a serious deactivation of HBEA catalyst due to carbonaceous deposits. As C3H6 did not adsorbed on the surface of CeO2 and could be oxidized to CO2 at high temperatures by CeO2, the addition of CeO2 to HBEA improved the propene poisoning resistance of HBEA-based catalysts. Thus, propene can inactivate Ce x /HBEA catalyst in two ways: 1) Propene competes the adsorptive sites with NO x and NH3 on surface of the catalysts, 2) The carbonaceous deposit formed on the surface of Ce x/HBEA catalyst by incomplete oxidation of propene will inhibit NH3-SCR reaction. At low temperatures, the competitive adsorption effects played a major role in inhibiting NH3-SCR activity. The decrements of NO x conversions below 300°C over Ce48/HBEA were mainly due to the competitive adsorption between propene and reactants. However, propene would desorb from the catalyst surface as shown in Fig. 7 when raising the reaction temperature. The inhibitory effect of competitive adsorption was weakened, but carbonaceous deposits would be formed at high temperature. The carbonaceous deposit played a major role in inhibiting NH3-SCR activity at high temperature. 3.7 Morphology characterization by HRTEM The catalytic activity is greatly affected by the morphology and structure, and therefore the morphology of the prepared catalysts were investigated by HRTEM. As shown in Fig. 8 , compared with pure HBEA catalyst, HBEA particles were covered by a layer of interconnected plate-like CeO2 nanoparticles in the HRTEM pattern of Ce48/HBEA catalyst, and the thickness of CeO2 shell is around 20nm. To further confirm the formation of HBEA-CeO2 core-shell structure, EDS line scans over the catalyst particle are shown in Fig. 8c, d. The Ce, Si, Al and O peak intensity variation along the scanning line was plotted on the bottom matching the profile of the catalyst particles. Si, Al and O were detected both in HBEA and in Ce48/HBEA because they are the fundamental components of HBEA. The intensity of element peak is proportional to its amounts. Line scan intensities of Si, O and Al presented a volcano-shaped plot for both HBEA and Ce48/HBEA, matching well with the spherical core of HBEA. Whereas, line scan intensity of Ce presented a plot with volcano-shape on both sides for Ce48/HBEA, indicating that spherical shell of CeO2 was formed outside of the HBEA core. Thus, HBEA-CeO2 core-shell structure was formed over Ce48/HBEA catalyst. It has been proved that the decrease of the catalytic activity over HBEA zeolite catalyst in the presence of C3H6 was primarily attributed to the deposition of carbonaceous species on the catalyst surface. Moreover, C3H6-TPD results show that C3H6 could not adsorb on the surface of CeO2. After the external surface of HBEA was covered by CeO2, the formation of carbonaceous deposits on the surface of HBEA was inhibited. The surface area and pore volume of Ce48/HBEA catalyst did not decrease after exposure to C3H6. Therefore, the CeO2 shell was responsible for the excellent propene poisoning resistance of Ce48/HBEA catalyst. 3.8 In situ DRIFTS studies on surface intermediates Fig. 9 shows the changes in the DRIFTS spectra of adsorbed species in a flow of 500ppmC3H6 +5% O2 +N2 balance over HBEA, Ce1/HBEA and Ce48/HBEA at 350°C. After the adsorption of C3H6 +O2 for 15min, the adsorbed COO− (1427cm−1, 1563cm−1, 1574cm−1 and 1593cm−1), CO (1672cm−1, 1682cm−1 and 1693cm−1), and CC around 1623cm−1 were observed on the DRIFTS spectra [40–42]. The results shows that C3H6 was oxidized to carboxylate as intermediates by the Ce x /HBEA catalyst. The absorption peaks of COO− was observed over the Ce48/HBEA catalyst in 5min, but after the adsorption of C3H6 +O2 for 15min, only a small absorption peak of COO− was observed over the HBEA catalyst. It indicates that the oxidation ability of Ce48/HBEA catalyst is stronger than that of HBEA catalyst. Fig. 10 shows the DRIFTS spectra of adsorbed species over HBEA and Ce48/HBEA at 350°C in a flow of NO+NH3 +C3H6 (when used)+5% O2 +N2 balance for 20min. The NH stretching vibration bands were observed at 3332cm−1, 3274cm−1, 3198cm−1 and 2709cm−1 [43]. The bands appeared at 1461cm−1 and 1331cm−1 was ascribed to the NH4 + species [44]. Two negative bands at 3730cm−1 and 3602cm−1 were observed due to the consumption of hydroxyl from SiOH and Si-OH-Al [42]. It is worth noting that new bands around 1690cm−1, 1685cm−1, 1563cm−1 and 1386cm−1 appeared when C3H6 was added to the feed gas. The bands around 1690cm−1 and 1685cm−1 were ascribed to CO species, and the bands around 1563cm−1 and 1386cm−1 were ascribed to COO−. Only a small CO band appeared over the HBEA catalyst, but both COO− and CO species were observed over the Ce48/HBEA catalyst. In addition, according to the results of C3H6 oxidation analysis shown in Fig. 4, C3H6 was easier to be oxidized to CO and CO2 when CeO2 was introduced into HBEA catalyst. These indicate that CeO2 could promote C3H6 oxidation to CO and CO2 by forming carboxylate intermediates. 4 Conclusions The propene poisoning resistance of HBEA zeolite catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO x was improved by doping CeO2. In the presence of propene, the Ce48/HBEA catalyst presented the highest NH3-SCR activity. Its NO x conversion was maintained at about 96% between 300 and 425°C. Only a minimal amount of N2O was formed over Ce48/HBEA catalyst. After poisoned by propene at 500°C for 30min, the surface area of HBEA was decreased by 63%. However, the surface area of the propene poisoned Ce48/HBEA hardly decreased compared with that of the fresh Ce48/HBEA. A core-shell structure was observed in the HRTEM pattern of Ce48/HBEA catalyst. After the external surface of HBEA was covered by CeO2, the formation of carbonaceous deposits on the surface of HBEA was inhibited. The order of C3H6 adsorption capacity was HBEA>Ce48/HBEA>CeO2. The DRIFTS experiments show that carboxylate intermediates were formed during NH3-SCR in the presence of C3H6. Ceria helped resist propene impact in two ways: 1) Ceria inhibited the adsorption of C3H6, 2) Ceria promoted C3H6 oxidaiton. As a result, the propene resistance of HBEA catalyst was improved by doping CeO2. These results are crucial to develop active zeolite-based SCR catalysts for diesel engines in practice. coredata.dc:description: The improvement of hydrocarbon resistance is a challenge for developing HBEA zeolite-based catalysts for NH3-SCR of NO x from diesel engine exhausts. HBEA zeolite was deactivated rapidly by propene during the NH3 selective catalytic reduction of NO x . The carbonaceous deposits formed by incomplete combustion of propene were responsible for the deactivation. The propene poisoning resistance of HBEA catalyst could be improved by doping CeO2. The Ce x /HBEA catalyst was prepared by impregnation method. The Ce48/HBEA catalyst showed the highest NO x conversion among the prepared catalysts. In the presence of propene, NO x conversion of Ce48/HBEA was above 92% in the temperature range of 300–450°C with GHSV of 150,000h−1. The N2 selectivity was above 96% between 175°C and 500°C for the Ce48/HBEA catalyst. Moreover, HBEA coated by CeO2 core-shell structure was formed in the Ce48/HBEA catalyst. Propene was mainly oxidized to CO2 by O2 over the CeO2 shell, which protected HBEA from propene poisoning. NH4 + and COO− as intermediates during NH3-SCR of NO x in the presence of C3H6 was observed on the DRIFTS spectra. These results show that the Ce48/HBEA catalyst with the core-shell structure is a potential candidate to control NO x emissions from diesel engine.
coredata.dc:title: Promotional effect of CeO2 on the propene poisoning resistance of HBEA zeolite catalyst for NH3-SCR of NO x
